question.text: Normally algae show a haplontic life cycle. Polysiphonia and Fucus are exceptions to this rule. The correct option depicting their classes and life cycles is

options.text: Polysiphonia is a green alga with haplo-diplontic life cycle and Fucus is a red alga with diplontic life cycle
Polysiphonia is a green alga with a diplontic life cycle and Fucus is a red alga with haplo-diplontic life cycle
Polysiphonia is a red alga with haplo-diplontic life cycle and Fucus is a brown alga with diplontic life cycle
Polysiphonia is a red alga with diplontic life cycle and Fucus is a brown alga with haplo-diplontic life cycle

solution.text:
The diplontic life cycle is a cycle in which the diploid sporophyte is the dominant, photosynthetic, independent phase of the plant. The gametophytic phase is represented by the single to the few-celled haploid gametophyte. It is seen in all seed-bearing plants gymnosperms and angiosperms. It is also seen in the brown alga Fucus.

Haplo-diplontic life cycle is a cycle in which a dominant, independent, photosynthetic, thalloid, or erect phase is represented by a haploid gametophyte, and it alternates with the short-lived, multicellular sporophyte totally or partially dependent on the gametophyte. This is seen in bryophytes, in the brown alga Ectocarpus and the red algae Polysiphonia
